sentences.text: THE ISSUE

rhetClass.text: THE ISSUE

sentences.text: Entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder (claimed as posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD)).

rhetClass.text: Entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder (claimed as posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD)).

sentences.text: REPRESENTATION

rhetClass.text: REPRESENTATION

rhetClass.text: Veteran represented by:Disabled American Veterans

sentences.text: S. Baxter, Associate Counsel

sentences.text: INTRODUCTION

rhetClass.text: INTRODUCTION

sentences.text: The Veteran served on active duty from November 1980 to October 1990.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran served on active duty from November 1980 to October 1990.

sentences.text: This matter comes before the Board of Veterans' Appeals from a February 2009 rating decision of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Regional Office (RO) in Los Angles, California.

rhetClass.text: This matter comes before the Board of Veterans' Appeals from a February 2009 rating decision of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Regional Office (RO) in Los Angles, California.

sentences.text: In his appeal, the Veteran requested a hearing.

rhetClass.text: In his appeal, the Veteran requested a hearing.

sentences.text: Accordingly, the Veteran was scheduled for a Board hearing in December 2016, but he did not appear for that hearing.

rhetClass.text: Accordingly, the Veteran was scheduled for a Board hearing in December 2016, but he did not appear for that hearing.

sentences.text: To date, the Veteran has not requested that his hearing be rescheduled.

rhetClass.text: To date, the Veteran has not requested that his hearing be rescheduled.

sentences.text: Therefore, the Board finds the Veteran's request for a hearing to be withdrawn.

rhetClass.text: Therefore, the Board finds the Veteran's request for a hearing to be withdrawn.

polarity.text: Therefore, the Board finds the Veteran's request for a hearing to be withdrawn.

ruleID.text: Therefore, the Board finds the Veteran's request for a hearing to be withdrawn.

sentences.text: The Veteran filed a substantive appeal on the issues of entitlement to service connection for hearing loss in his right and left ear, entitlement to service connection for tinnitus, and entitlement to service connection for hepatitis B.  These issues were granted in a February 2014 and March 2016 rating decisions.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran filed a substantive appeal on the issues of entitlement to service connection for hearing loss in his right and left ear, entitlement to service connection for tinnitus, and entitlement to service connection for hepatitis B.  These issues were granted in a February 2014 and March 2016 rating decisions.

sentences.text: Therefore, these issues are no longer before the Board.

rhetClass.text: Therefore, these issues are no longer before the Board.

sentences.text: FINDINGS OF FACT

rhetClass.text: FINDINGS OF FACT

sentences.text: The Veteran does not have PTSD.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran does not have PTSD.

sentences.text: The Veteran's acquired psychiatric disorder was not manifest during service.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran's acquired psychiatric disorder was not manifest during service.

polarity.text: The Veteran's acquired psychiatric disorder was not manifest during service.

ruleID.text: The Veteran's acquired psychiatric disorder was not manifest during service.

sentences.text: Symptoms delusions were not chronic in service or continuous after service separation.

rhetClass.text: Symptoms delusions were not chronic in service or continuous after service separation.

sentences.text: The Veteran's delusional disorder did not manifest to a compensable degree within one year of separation from service.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran's delusional disorder did not manifest to a compensable degree within one year of separation from service.

polarity.text: The Veteran's delusional disorder did not manifest to a compensable degree within one year of separation from service.

ruleID.text: The Veteran's delusional disorder did not manifest to a compensable degree within one year of separation from service.

sentences.text: The Veteran's psychiatric disorders are not related to service.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran's psychiatric disorders are not related to service.

sentences.text: CONCLUSION OF LAW

rhetClass.text: CONCLUSION OF LAW

sentences.text: The criteria for service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD, are not met.

rhetClass.text: The criteria for service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD, are not met.

polarity.text: The criteria for service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD, are not met.

ruleID.text: The criteria for service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD, are not met.

sentences.text: REASONS AND BASES FOR FINDINGS AND CONCLUSION

rhetClass.text: REASONS AND BASES FOR FINDINGS AND CONCLUSION

sentences.text: I.  Duties to Notify and Assist

rhetClass.text: I.  Duties to Notify and Assist

sentences.text: VA satisfied its duty to notify the Veteran pursuant to the Veterans Claims Assistance Act of 2000 (VCAA) in an October 2008 letter.

rhetClass.text: VA satisfied its duty to notify the Veteran pursuant to the Veterans Claims Assistance Act of 2000 (VCAA) in an October 2008 letter.

sentences.text: Concerning the duty to assist, the record reflects that VA has made reasonable efforts to obtain relevant records adequately identified by the Veteran, including his service treatment records, post-service treatment records, and VA examination reports.

rhetClass.text: Concerning the duty to assist, the record reflects that VA has made reasonable efforts to obtain relevant records adequately identified by the Veteran, including his service treatment records, post-service treatment records, and VA examination reports.

sentences.text: In summary, the Veteran was notified and aware of the evidence needed to substantiate his claim, the avenues through which he might obtain such evidence, and the allocation of responsibilities between himself and VA in obtaining such evidence.

rhetClass.text: In summary, the Veteran was notified and aware of the evidence needed to substantiate his claim, the avenues through which he might obtain such evidence, and the allocation of responsibilities between himself and VA in obtaining such evidence.

sentences.text: He was an active participant in the claims process submitting evidence and argument and presenting for a VA examination.

rhetClass.text: He was an active participant in the claims process submitting evidence and argument and presenting for a VA examination.

sentences.text: Thus, he was provided with a meaningful opportunity to participate in the claims process and has done so.

rhetClass.text: Thus, he was provided with a meaningful opportunity to participate in the claims process and has done so.

sentences.text: Any error in the sequence of events or content of the notices is not shown to have any effect on the case or to cause injury to the Veteran.

rhetClass.text: Any error in the sequence of events or content of the notices is not shown to have any effect on the case or to cause injury to the Veteran.

sentences.text: Therefore, any such error is harmless and does not prohibit consideration of these matters on the merits.

rhetClass.text: Therefore, any such error is harmless and does not prohibit consideration of these matters on the merits.

polarity.text: Therefore, any such error is harmless and does not prohibit consideration of these matters on the merits.

ruleID.text: Therefore, any such error is harmless and does not prohibit consideration of these matters on the merits.

sentences.text: See Dingess/Hartman v. Nicholson, 19 Vet. App. 473 (2006); see also ATD Corp.

rhetClass.text: See Dingess/Hartman v. Nicholson, 19 Vet. App. 473 (2006); see also ATD Corp.

sentences.text: v@! Lydall, Inc., 159 F.3d 534, 549 (Fed. Cir. 1998).

rhetClass.text: v@! Lydall, Inc., 159 F.3d 534, 549 (Fed. Cir. 1998).

sentences.text: II.

rhetClass.text: II.

sentences.text: Service Connection

rhetClass.text: Service Connection

sentences.text: Service connection for VA compensation purposes will be granted for a disability resulting from disease or personal injury incurred in the line of duty or for aggravation of a preexisting disease or injury in the active military, naval, or air service.

rhetClass.text: Service connection for VA compensation purposes will be granted for a disability resulting from disease or personal injury incurred in the line of duty or for aggravation of a preexisting disease or injury in the active military, naval, or air service.

sentences.text: Service connection may be granted for any disease diagnosed after discharge, when all the evidence, including that pertinent to service, establishes that the disease was incurred in service.

rhetClass.text: Service connection may be granted for any disease diagnosed after discharge, when all the evidence, including that pertinent to service, establishes that the disease was incurred in service.

sentences.text: In order to establish service connection for the claimed disorder, there must be

rhetClass.text: In order to establish service connection for the claimed disorder, there must be

sentences.text: (1) competent evidence of a current disability; (2) medical, or in certain circumstances, lay evidence of in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) competent evidence of a nexus between the claimed in-service disease or injury and the current disability.

rhetClass.text: (1) competent evidence of a current disability; (2) medical, or in certain circumstances, lay evidence of in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) competent evidence of a nexus between the claimed in-service disease or injury and the current disability.

sentences.text: See Hickson v. West, 12 Vet. App. 247, 253 (1999).

rhetClass.text: See Hickson v. West, 12 Vet. App. 247, 253 (1999).

sentences.text: The determination as to whether these requirements are met is based on an analysis of all the evidence of record and the evaluation of its credibility and probative value.

rhetClass.text: The determination as to whether these requirements are met is based on an analysis of all the evidence of record and the evaluation of its credibility and probative value.

sentences.text: See Baldwin v. West, 13 Vet. App. 1, 8 (1999).

rhetClass.text: See Baldwin v. West, 13 Vet. App. 1, 8 (1999).

sentences.text: There are particular requirements for establishing entitlement to service connection for PTSD in 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304 (f) that are separate from those for establishing service connection generally.

rhetClass.text: There are particular requirements for establishing entitlement to service connection for PTSD in 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304 (f) that are separate from those for establishing service connection generally.

sentences.text: Arzio v. Shinseki, 602 F.3d 1343, 1347 (Fed. Cir. 2010).

rhetClass.text: Arzio v. Shinseki, 602 F.3d 1343, 1347 (Fed. Cir. 2010).

sentences.text: Those requirements are: (1) a diagnosis of PTSD in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125 ; (2) credible supporting evidence that the claimed in-service stressor actually occurred; and (3) medical evidence of a causal nexus between current symptomatology and the specific claimed in- service stressor.

rhetClass.text: Those requirements are: (1) a diagnosis of PTSD in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125 ; (2) credible supporting evidence that the claimed in-service stressor actually occurred; and (3) medical evidence of a causal nexus between current symptomatology and the specific claimed in- service stressor.

sentences.text: If a stressor claimed by a Veteran is related to the veteran's fear of hostile military or terrorist activity and a VA psychiatrist or psychologist confirms that the claimed stressor is adequate to support a diagnosis of PTSD and that the Veteran's symptoms are related to the claimed stressor, in the absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, and provided the claimed stressor is consistent with the places, types, and circumstances of the Veteran's service, the Veteran's lay testimony alone may establish the occurrence of the claimed in-service stressor.

rhetClass.text: If a stressor claimed by a Veteran is related to the veteran's fear of hostile military or terrorist activity and a VA psychiatrist or psychologist confirms that the claimed stressor is adequate to support a diagnosis of PTSD and that the Veteran's symptoms are related to the claimed stressor, in the absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, and provided the claimed stressor is consistent with the places, types, and circumstances of the Veteran's service, the Veteran's lay testimony alone may establish the occurrence of the claimed in-service stressor.

sentences.text: "Fear of hostile military activity" is defined to mean that a veteran experienced, witnessed, or was confronted with an event or circumstance that involved actual or threatened death or serious injury, or a threat to the physical integrity of the Veteran or others, and the Veteran's response to the event or circumstance involved a psychological or psycho-physiological state of fear, helplessness, or horror.

rhetClass.text: "Fear of hostile military activity" is defined to mean that a veteran experienced, witnessed, or was confronted with an event or circumstance that involved actual or threatened death or serious injury, or a threat to the physical integrity of the Veteran or others, and the Veteran's response to the event or circumstance involved a psychological or psycho-physiological state of fear, helplessness, or horror.

sentences.text: Id.

rhetClass.text: Id.

sentences.text: The list of examples of such an event or circumstance specifically includes incoming mortar, rocket, and sniper fire.

rhetClass.text: The list of examples of such an event or circumstance specifically includes incoming mortar, rocket, and sniper fire.

sentences.text: Id.

rhetClass.text: Id.

sentences.text: Service connection may also be granted for a psychosis when it is shown to have been manifested to a compensable degree within one year of separation from service.

rhetClass.text: Service connection may also be granted for a psychosis when it is shown to have been manifested to a compensable degree within one year of separation from service.

sentences.text: According to 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.384 (2017), a "psychosis" includes the following specific disorders: brief psychotic disorder, delusional disorder, psychotic disorder due to general medical condition, psychotic disorder not otherwise specified (NOS), schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, shared psychotic disorder, and substance-induced psychotic disorder.

rhetClass.text: According to 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.384 (2017), a "psychosis" includes the following specific disorders: brief psychotic disorder, delusional disorder, psychotic disorder due to general medical condition, psychotic disorder not otherwise specified (NOS), schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, shared psychotic disorder, and substance-induced psychotic disorder.

sentences.text: Evidence of continuity of symptomatology from the time of service until the present is required where the chronicity of a chronic condition manifested during service either has not been established or might reasonably be questioned.

rhetClass.text: Evidence of continuity of symptomatology from the time of service until the present is required where the chronicity of a chronic condition manifested during service either has not been established or might reasonably be questioned.

sentences.text: Insofar as the appellant presents an argument of continuity of symptomatology, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit recently held in Walker v. Shinseki that service connection can be based on continuity of symptomatology only with respect to the specific chronic diseases listed in 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.309 (a).

rhetClass.text: Insofar as the appellant presents an argument of continuity of symptomatology, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit recently held in Walker v. Shinseki that service connection can be based on continuity of symptomatology only with respect to the specific chronic diseases listed in 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.309 (a).

sentences.text: Walker v. Shinseki, 708 F.3d 1331, 1337 (Fed.Cir. 2013).

rhetClass.text: Walker v. Shinseki, 708 F.3d 1331, 1337 (Fed.Cir. 2013).

sentences.text: On the other hand, personality disorders are not compensable diseases or injuries within the meaning of Veterans' benefits law.

rhetClass.text: On the other hand, personality disorders are not compensable diseases or injuries within the meaning of Veterans' benefits law.

sentences.text: 38 C.F.R. Â§Â§ 3.303 (c), 4.9 (2017); Winn v. Brown, 8 Vet. App. 510, 516 (1996); Beno v. Principi, 3 Vet. App. 439 (1992).

rhetClass.text: 38 C.F.R. Â§Â§ 3.303 (c), 4.9 (2017); Winn v. Brown, 8 Vet. App. 510, 516 (1996); Beno v. Principi, 3 Vet. App. 439 (1992).

sentences.text: The credibility and weight of all the evidence, including the medical evidence, should be assessed to determine its probative value, the evidence found to be persuasive or unpersuasive should be accounted for, and reasons should be provided for rejecting any evidence favorable to the claimant.

rhetClass.text: The credibility and weight of all the evidence, including the medical evidence, should be assessed to determine its probative value, the evidence found to be persuasive or unpersuasive should be accounted for, and reasons should be provided for rejecting any evidence favorable to the claimant.

sentences.text: See Masors v. Derwinski, 2 Vet. App. 181 (1992).

rhetClass.text: See Masors v. Derwinski, 2 Vet. App. 181 (1992).

sentences.text: Equal weight is not accorded to each piece of evidence contained in the record; every item of evidence does not have the same probative value.

rhetClass.text: Equal weight is not accorded to each piece of evidence contained in the record; every item of evidence does not have the same probative value.

sentences.text: It is the Board's responsibility to determine whether a preponderance of the evidence supports the claim or whether the evidence is in relative equipoise, with the Veteran prevailing in either event, or whether there is a preponderance of evidence against the claim, in which case the claim must be denied.

rhetClass.text: It is the Board's responsibility to determine whether a preponderance of the evidence supports the claim or whether the evidence is in relative equipoise, with the Veteran prevailing in either event, or whether there is a preponderance of evidence against the claim, in which case the claim must be denied.

sentences.text: See Gilbert v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 49 (1990).

rhetClass.text: See Gilbert v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 49 (1990).

sentences.text: The Veteran asserts that his claimed acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD is a result of his military service.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran asserts that his claimed acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD is a result of his military service.

polarity.text: The Veteran asserts that his claimed acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD is a result of his military service.

ruleID.text: The Veteran asserts that his claimed acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD is a result of his military service.

sentences.text: The Veteran's service treatment records (STRs) contain no complaints of, treatment for or diagnosis of symptoms related to an acquired psychiatric disorder.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran's service treatment records (STRs) contain no complaints of, treatment for or diagnosis of symptoms related to an acquired psychiatric disorder.

sentences.text: Post service records reveal that the Veteran was diagnosed with PTSD.

rhetClass.text: Post service records reveal that the Veteran was diagnosed with PTSD.

sentences.text: A March 2008 VA mental health assessment diagnosed the Veteran with an adjustment disorder.

rhetClass.text: A March 2008 VA mental health assessment diagnosed the Veteran with an adjustment disorder.

sentences.text: An August 2012 VA psychiatry note, documented that the Veteran was diagnosed with depression, PTSD, and psychosis.

rhetClass.text: An August 2012 VA psychiatry note, documented that the Veteran was diagnosed with depression, PTSD, and psychosis.

sentences.text: In August 2012, the Veteran was afforded a VA PTSD examination.

rhetClass.text: In August 2012, the Veteran was afforded a VA PTSD examination.

sentences.text: The Veteran reported that he had sleep problems, panic attacks, and depression.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran reported that he had sleep problems, panic attacks, and depression.

sentences.text: The Veteran indicated that he felt people were after him.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran indicated that he felt people were after him.

sentences.text: He denied any suicidal and homicidal ideations.

rhetClass.text: He denied any suicidal and homicidal ideations.

sentences.text: The Veteran reported that he did not participate in any combat activity.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran reported that he did not participate in any combat activity.

sentences.text: The examiner indicated that he reviewed the claims file and medical records.

rhetClass.text: The examiner indicated that he reviewed the claims file and medical records.

sentences.text: The examiner opined that the Veteran did not have a diagnosis of PTSD that conforms to DSM-5.

rhetClass.text: The examiner opined that the Veteran did not have a diagnosis of PTSD that conforms to DSM-5.

sentences.text: The examiner diagnosed the Veteran with delusional disorder and alcohol dependence.

rhetClass.text: The examiner diagnosed the Veteran with delusional disorder and alcohol dependence.

sentences.text: The examiner noted that the symptoms of nonbizarre, persecutory delusions were attributed to his delusion disorder.

rhetClass.text: The examiner noted that the symptoms of nonbizarre, persecutory delusions were attributed to his delusion disorder.

sentences.text: He further commented that the Veteran's delusions did not meet the criteria for schizophrenia.

rhetClass.text: He further commented that the Veteran's delusions did not meet the criteria for schizophrenia.

sentences.text: In April 2016, the Veteran was afforded another VA examination.

rhetClass.text: In April 2016, the Veteran was afforded another VA examination.

sentences.text: The Veteran reported that he participated in a training exercise in Korea when he encountered hostile opponents who did not know that they were in a training exercise without real bullets.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran reported that he participated in a training exercise in Korea when he encountered hostile opponents who did not know that they were in a training exercise without real bullets.

sentences.text: The Veteran reported that he felt people were out to get him.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran reported that he felt people were out to get him.

sentences.text: He also reported that he was not sure who but he felt that others were often following or spying on him The examiner indicated that he reviewed the Veteran's claims file.

rhetClass.text: He also reported that he was not sure who but he felt that others were often following or spying on him The examiner indicated that he reviewed the Veteran's claims file.

sentences.text: The examiner opined that the Veteran did not meet the DSM-5 criteria for PTSD.

rhetClass.text: The examiner opined that the Veteran did not meet the DSM-5 criteria for PTSD.

sentences.text: The examiner indicated that the Veteran had the following symptoms, depressed mood, anxiety, suspiciousness, chronic sleep impairment, mild memory loss, as forgetting names, directions or recent events, impaired judgment, disturbances of motivation and mood, difficulty in establishing and maintaining effective work and social relationships, difficulty adapting to stressful circumstance, including work or a work like setting, inability to establish and maintain effective relationships, impaired impulse control, such as unprovoked irritability with periods of violence, and persistent delusions or hallucinations.

rhetClass.text: The examiner indicated that the Veteran had the following symptoms, depressed mood, anxiety, suspiciousness, chronic sleep impairment, mild memory loss, as forgetting names, directions or recent events, impaired judgment, disturbances of motivation and mood, difficulty in establishing and maintaining effective work and social relationships, difficulty adapting to stressful circumstance, including work or a work like setting, inability to establish and maintain effective relationships, impaired impulse control, such as unprovoked irritability with periods of violence, and persistent delusions or hallucinations.

sentences.text: The Veteran's symptoms caused him to have an occupational and social impairment with deficiencies in most areas, such as work, school, family relations, judgment, thinking, and/or mood.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran's symptoms caused him to have an occupational and social impairment with deficiencies in most areas, such as work, school, family relations, judgment, thinking, and/or mood.

sentences.text: The examiner opined that it was less likely than not that the Veteran had a diagnosis of PTSD.

rhetClass.text: The examiner opined that it was less likely than not that the Veteran had a diagnosis of PTSD.

sentences.text: She further opined that the Veteran's delusional disorder and alcohol use disorder was unrelated to his military service.

rhetClass.text: She further opined that the Veteran's delusional disorder and alcohol use disorder was unrelated to his military service.

sentences.text: She commented that her opinion was based on thorough C-file review, review of all available medical records and current peer reviewed medical literature.

rhetClass.text: She commented that her opinion was based on thorough C-file review, review of all available medical records and current peer reviewed medical literature.

sentences.text: She noted that the Veteran was currently prescribed Zyprexa and Prozac to treat delusions, depression, and anxiety.

rhetClass.text: She noted that the Veteran was currently prescribed Zyprexa and Prozac to treat delusions, depression, and anxiety.

sentences.text: The Board finds that service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD, is not warranted.

rhetClass.text: The Board finds that service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD, is not warranted.

polarity.text: The Board finds that service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD, is not warranted.

ruleID.text: The Board finds that service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD, is not warranted.

sentences.text: To that end, regardless of the Veteran's claimed stressors, his claim for PTSD must be denied because the preponderance of the evidence reflects that he does not have a diagnosis of PTSD in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125.

rhetClass.text: To that end, regardless of the Veteran's claimed stressors, his claim for PTSD must be denied because the preponderance of the evidence reflects that he does not have a diagnosis of PTSD in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125.

polarity.text: To that end, regardless of the Veteran's claimed stressors, his claim for PTSD must be denied because the preponderance of the evidence reflects that he does not have a diagnosis of PTSD in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125.

ruleID.text: To that end, regardless of the Veteran's claimed stressors, his claim for PTSD must be denied because the preponderance of the evidence reflects that he does not have a diagnosis of PTSD in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125.

sentences.text: Here, VA examiners have consistently found that the Veteran did not meet the criteria for a PTSD diagnosis.

rhetClass.text: Here, VA examiners have consistently found that the Veteran did not meet the criteria for a PTSD diagnosis.

sentences.text: As to the Veteran's lay statements, while Veteran is competent to testify as to some matters of diagnosis and etiology, the question of whether a Veteran has a diagnosis of PTSD is the type of medical issue as to an internal, non-observable process as to which lay testimony is not competent.

rhetClass.text: As to the Veteran's lay statements, while Veteran is competent to testify as to some matters of diagnosis and etiology, the question of whether a Veteran has a diagnosis of PTSD is the type of medical issue as to an internal, non-observable process as to which lay testimony is not competent.

sentences.text: See Clemons v. Shinseki, 23 Vet. App. 1, 6 (2009) ("It is generally the province of medical professionals to diagnose or label a mental condition, not the claimant"); 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304 (f) (specifically requiring medical evidence diagnosing PTSD).

rhetClass.text: See Clemons v. Shinseki, 23 Vet. App. 1, 6 (2009) ("It is generally the province of medical professionals to diagnose or label a mental condition, not the claimant"); 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304 (f) (specifically requiring medical evidence diagnosing PTSD).

sentences.text: Consequently, the Veteran's statements as to whether he has a diagnosis of PTSD are not competent.

rhetClass.text: Consequently, the Veteran's statements as to whether he has a diagnosis of PTSD are not competent.

sentences.text: Next, the Board finds that the Veteran's psychiatric disorders were not chronic in service.

rhetClass.text: Next, the Board finds that the Veteran's psychiatric disorders were not chronic in service.

polarity.text: Next, the Board finds that the Veteran's psychiatric disorders were not chronic in service.

ruleID.text: Next, the Board finds that the Veteran's psychiatric disorders were not chronic in service.

sentences.text: Service treatment records are negative for any complaints, diagnoses, or treatment for a psychiatric disorder.

rhetClass.text: Service treatment records are negative for any complaints, diagnoses, or treatment for a psychiatric disorder.

sentences.text: In a March 1987 VA periodic medical examination, the Veteran had a normal clinical psychiatric evaluation and a psychiatric disorder was not noted.

rhetClass.text: In a March 1987 VA periodic medical examination, the Veteran had a normal clinical psychiatric evaluation and a psychiatric disorder was not noted.

sentences.text: As such, symptoms of a psychiatric disorder were not chronic in service.

rhetClass.text: As such, symptoms of a psychiatric disorder were not chronic in service.

sentences.text: The Board further finds that the Veteran's symptoms of delusions have not been continuous since service separation.

rhetClass.text: The Board further finds that the Veteran's symptoms of delusions have not been continuous since service separation.

polarity.text: The Board further finds that the Veteran's symptoms of delusions have not been continuous since service separation.

ruleID.text: The Board further finds that the Veteran's symptoms of delusions have not been continuous since service separation.

sentences.text: The Veteran was not diagnosed with a delusional disorder until August 2012, nearly 20 years after his military service.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran was not diagnosed with a delusional disorder until August 2012, nearly 20 years after his military service.

sentences.text: The Board finds that this evidence tends to show that the Veteran's symptoms of delusions began many years after service separation.

rhetClass.text: The Board finds that this evidence tends to show that the Veteran's symptoms of delusions began many years after service separation.

polarity.text: The Board finds that this evidence tends to show that the Veteran's symptoms of delusions began many years after service separation.

ruleID.text: The Board finds that this evidence tends to show that the Veteran's symptoms of delusions began many years after service separation.

sentences.text: See Maxson v. Gober, 230 F.3d 1330, 1333 (Fed. Cir. 2000) (lengthy period of absence of medical complaints for condition can be considered as a factor for consideration in deciding a claim).

rhetClass.text: See Maxson v. Gober, 230 F.3d 1330, 1333 (Fed. Cir. 2000) (lengthy period of absence of medical complaints for condition can be considered as a factor for consideration in deciding a claim).

sentences.text: For these reasons, the Board finds that the Veteran's psychiatric disorder did not manifest to a compensable degree within one year from service separation and symptoms of a psychiatric disorder have not been continuous since service separation.

rhetClass.text: For these reasons, the Board finds that the Veteran's psychiatric disorder did not manifest to a compensable degree within one year from service separation and symptoms of a psychiatric disorder have not been continuous since service separation.

polarity.text: For these reasons, the Board finds that the Veteran's psychiatric disorder did not manifest to a compensable degree within one year from service separation and symptoms of a psychiatric disorder have not been continuous since service separation.

ruleID.text: For these reasons, the Board finds that the Veteran's psychiatric disorder did not manifest to a compensable degree within one year from service separation and symptoms of a psychiatric disorder have not been continuous since service separation.

sentences.text: Next, the Board finds that the weight of the evidence of record does not demonstrate that the Veteran's psychiatric disorders are related to service.

rhetClass.text: Next, the Board finds that the weight of the evidence of record does not demonstrate that the Veteran's psychiatric disorders are related to service.

polarity.text: Next, the Board finds that the weight of the evidence of record does not demonstrate that the Veteran's psychiatric disorders are related to service.

sentences.text: The evidence includes an August 2012 and an April 2016 VA examination reports.

ruleTree.label: The veteran has a disability that is service-connected.

nodes.label: The veteran has a present disability.
The veteranâ€™s claim is for PTSD, and the veteran presently has a diagnosis of PTSD supported by medical evidence diagnosing the condition in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125(a).
The veteran suffered an in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury in line of duty.
The veteran suffered an in-service incurrence of a disease or injury.
The veteran suffered an injury or contracted a disease during active military service.
The veteranâ€™s claim is for PTSD, and there is credible supporting evidence that the claimed in-service stressor occurred.
There is adequate evidence that the veteran suffered from the claimed disease or injury while in service.
The injury or disease did not preexist entry into service.
The veteran is presumed to have been in sound condition when examined, accepted, and enrolled for service (the presumption of sound condition or presumption of soundness).

The veteran served in the active military, naval, or air service, during a period of war or after December 31, 1946, and clear and unmistakable evidence demonstrates that the injury or disease existed before acceptance and enrollment and was not aggravated by such service.
The veteran suffered an in-service aggravation of a disease or injury.
The injury or disease preexisted entry into service.
There was an aggravation during service.
The presumption of aggravation has been satisfied.
Based on clear and unmistakable evidence (obvious or manifest) that is undebatable, there is a specific finding that the increase in disability is due to the natural progress of the disease.
The disability is a result of the veteranâ€™s own willful misconduct or abuse of alcohol or drugs.
There is a causal relationship [nexus] between the present disability and the injury, disease, or aggravation of a preexisting injury or disease incurred during active duty.
The veteranâ€™s claim is for PTSD, and there is a link, established by medical evidence, between current symptoms and an in-service stressor.

text:
Citation Nr: 1802031	
Decision Date: 01/11/18    Archive Date: 01/23/18

DOCKET NO.   14-09 913	)	DATE
	)
	)

On appeal from the
Department of Veterans Affairs Regional Office in Los Angeles, California


THE ISSUE

Entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder (claimed as posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD)).  



REPRESENTATION

Veteran represented by:	Disabled American Veterans


ATTORNEY FOR THE BOARD

S. Baxter, Associate Counsel





INTRODUCTION


The Veteran served on active duty from November 1980 to October 1990. 

This matter comes before the Board of Veterans' Appeals from a February 2009 rating decision of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Regional Office (RO) in Los Angles, California.  

In his appeal, the Veteran requested a hearing.  Accordingly, the Veteran was scheduled for a Board hearing in December 2016, but he did not appear for that hearing.  To date, the Veteran has not requested that his hearing be rescheduled.  Therefore, the Board finds the Veteran's request for a hearing to be withdrawn.  38 C.F.R. Â§ 20.702 (d)(2017).

The Veteran filed a substantive appeal on the issues of entitlement to service connection for hearing loss in his right and left ear, entitlement to service connection for tinnitus, and entitlement to service connection for hepatitis B.  These issues were granted in a February 2014 and March 2016 rating decisions.  Therefore, these issues are no longer before the Board.


FINDINGS OF FACT

1.  The Veteran does not have PTSD.

2.  The Veteran's acquired psychiatric disorder was not manifest during service.

3.  Symptoms delusions were not chronic in service or continuous after service separation.

4. The Veteran's delusional disorder did not manifest to a compensable degree within one year of separation from service. 

5.  The Veteran's psychiatric disorders are not related to service.


CONCLUSION OF LAW

The criteria for service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD, are not met.  38 U.S.C. Â§ 1110 (West 2012); 38 C.F.R. Â§Â§ 3.102, 3.303, 3.304 (2017).


REASONS AND BASES FOR FINDINGS AND CONCLUSION

I.  Duties to Notify and Assist

VA satisfied its duty to notify the Veteran pursuant to the Veterans Claims Assistance Act of 2000 (VCAA) in an October 2008 letter.  38 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 5100, 5102-5103A, 5106, 5107, 5126 (West 2014); 38 C.F.R. Â§Â§ 3.102, 3.156(a), 3.159, 3.326(a), 4.2 (2017).  

Concerning the duty to assist, the record reflects that VA has made reasonable efforts to obtain relevant records adequately identified by the Veteran, including his service treatment records, post-service treatment records, and VA examination reports.

In summary, the Veteran was notified and aware of the evidence needed to substantiate his claim, the avenues through which he might obtain such evidence, and the allocation of responsibilities between himself and VA in obtaining such evidence.  He was an active participant in the claims process submitting evidence and argument and presenting for a VA examination.  Thus, he was provided with a meaningful opportunity to participate in the claims process and has done so.  Any error in the sequence of events or content of the notices is not shown to have any effect on the case or to cause injury to the Veteran.  Therefore, any such error is harmless and does not prohibit consideration of these matters on the merits.  See Dingess/Hartman v. Nicholson, 19 Vet. App. 473 (2006); see also ATD Corp. v. Lydall, Inc., 159 F.3d 534, 549 (Fed. Cir. 1998).

II.  Service Connection 

Service connection for VA compensation purposes will be granted for a disability resulting from disease or personal injury incurred in the line of duty or for aggravation of a preexisting disease or injury in the active military, naval, or air service. 38 U.S.C. Â§ 1131; 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.303(a).  Service connection may be granted for any disease diagnosed after discharge, when all the evidence, including that pertinent to service, establishes that the disease was incurred in service.  38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.303 (d).

In order to establish service connection for the claimed disorder, there must be 
 (1) competent evidence of a current disability; (2) medical, or in certain circumstances, lay evidence of in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) competent evidence of a nexus between the claimed in-service disease or injury and the current disability.  See Hickson v. West, 12 Vet. App. 247, 253 (1999).  The determination as to whether these requirements are met is based on an analysis of all the evidence of record and the evaluation of its credibility and probative value.  See Baldwin v. West, 13 Vet. App. 1, 8 (1999).

There are particular requirements for establishing entitlement to service connection for PTSD in 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304 (f) that are separate from those for establishing service connection generally.  Arzio v. Shinseki, 602 F.3d 1343, 1347 (Fed. Cir. 2010).  Those requirements are: (1) a diagnosis of PTSD in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125 ; (2) credible supporting evidence that the claimed in-service stressor actually occurred; and (3) medical evidence of a causal nexus between current symptomatology and the specific claimed in- service stressor.  38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304 (f).  If a stressor claimed by a Veteran is related to the veteran's fear of hostile military or terrorist activity and a VA psychiatrist or psychologist confirms that the claimed stressor is adequate to support a diagnosis of PTSD and that the Veteran's symptoms are related to the claimed stressor, in the absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, and provided the claimed stressor is consistent with the places, types, and circumstances of the Veteran's service, the Veteran's lay testimony alone may establish the occurrence of the claimed in-service stressor. 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304 (f)(3).  "Fear of hostile military activity" is defined to mean that a veteran experienced, witnessed, or was confronted with an event or circumstance that involved actual or threatened death or serious injury, or a threat to the physical integrity of the Veteran or others, and the Veteran's response to the event or circumstance involved a psychological or psycho-physiological state of fear, helplessness, or horror.  Id.  The list of examples of such an event or circumstance specifically includes incoming mortar, rocket, and sniper fire.  Id.  

Service connection may also be granted for a psychosis when it is shown to have been manifested to a compensable degree within one year of separation from service.  38 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 1101, 1112, 1113, 1137 (2012); 38 C.F.R. Â§Â§ 3.307, 3.309 (2016).  According to 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.384 (2017), a "psychosis" includes the following specific disorders: brief psychotic disorder, delusional disorder, psychotic disorder due to general medical condition, psychotic disorder not otherwise specified (NOS), schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, shared psychotic disorder, and substance-induced psychotic disorder.

Evidence of continuity of symptomatology from the time of service until the present is required where the chronicity of a chronic condition manifested during service either has not been established or might reasonably be questioned.  38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.303 (b).  Insofar as the appellant presents an argument of continuity of symptomatology, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit recently held in Walker v. Shinseki that service connection can be based on continuity of symptomatology only with respect to the specific chronic diseases listed in 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.309 (a).  Walker v. Shinseki, 708 F.3d 1331, 1337 (Fed.Cir. 2013). 

On the other hand, personality disorders are not compensable diseases or injuries within the meaning of Veterans' benefits law.  38 C.F.R. Â§Â§ 3.303 (c), 4.9 (2017); Winn v. Brown, 8 Vet. App. 510, 516 (1996); Beno v. Principi, 3 Vet. App. 439 (1992).  

The credibility and weight of all the evidence, including the medical evidence, should be assessed to determine its probative value, the evidence found to be persuasive or unpersuasive should be accounted for, and reasons should be provided for rejecting any evidence favorable to the claimant.  See Masors v. Derwinski, 2 Vet. App. 181 (1992).  Equal weight is not accorded to each piece of evidence contained in the record; every item of evidence does not have the same probative value. 

It is the Board's responsibility to determine whether a preponderance of the evidence supports the claim or whether the evidence is in relative equipoise, with the Veteran prevailing in either event, or whether there is a preponderance of evidence against the claim, in which case the claim must be denied.  See Gilbert v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 49 (1990).

The Veteran asserts that his claimed acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD is a result of his military service.

The Veteran's service treatment records (STRs) contain no complaints of, treatment for or diagnosis of symptoms related to an acquired psychiatric disorder.  

Post service records reveal that the Veteran was diagnosed with PTSD.  A March 2008 VA mental health assessment diagnosed the Veteran with an adjustment disorder.  An August 2012 VA psychiatry note, documented that the Veteran was diagnosed with depression, PTSD, and psychosis.  

In August 2012, the Veteran was afforded a VA PTSD examination.  The Veteran reported that he had sleep problems, panic attacks, and depression.  The Veteran indicated that he felt people were after him.  He denied any suicidal and homicidal ideations.  The Veteran reported that he did not participate in any combat activity.  The examiner indicated that he reviewed the claims file and medical records.  The examiner opined that the Veteran did not have a diagnosis of PTSD that conforms to DSM-5.  The examiner diagnosed the Veteran with delusional disorder and alcohol dependence.  The examiner noted that the symptoms of nonbizarre, persecutory delusions were attributed to his delusion disorder.  He further commented that the Veteran's delusions did not meet the criteria for schizophrenia.  
	
In April 2016, the Veteran was afforded another VA examination.  The Veteran reported that he participated in a training exercise in Korea when he encountered hostile opponents who did not know that they were in a training exercise without real bullets.  The Veteran reported that he felt people were out to get him.  He also reported that he was not sure who but he felt that others were often following or spying on him The examiner indicated that he reviewed the Veteran's claims file.  The examiner opined that the Veteran did not meet the DSM-5 criteria for PTSD.  The examiner indicated that the Veteran had the following symptoms, depressed mood, anxiety, suspiciousness, chronic sleep impairment, mild memory loss, as forgetting names, directions or recent events, impaired judgment, disturbances of motivation and mood, difficulty in establishing and maintaining effective work and social relationships, difficulty adapting to stressful circumstance, including work or a work like setting, inability to establish and maintain effective relationships, impaired impulse control, such as unprovoked irritability with periods of violence, and persistent delusions or hallucinations.   The Veteran's symptoms caused him to have an occupational and social impairment with deficiencies in most areas, such as work, school, family relations, judgment, thinking, and/or mood.  The examiner opined that it was less likely than not that the Veteran had a diagnosis of PTSD.  She further opined that the Veteran's delusional disorder and alcohol use disorder was unrelated to his military service.  She commented that her opinion was based on thorough C-file review, review of all available medical records and current peer reviewed medical literature.  She noted that the Veteran was currently prescribed Zyprexa and Prozac to treat delusions, depression, and anxiety.   

The Board finds that service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD, is not warranted.  To that end, regardless of the Veteran's claimed stressors, his claim for PTSD must be denied because the preponderance of the evidence reflects that he does not have a diagnosis of PTSD in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125.  Here, VA examiners have consistently found that the Veteran did not meet the criteria for a PTSD diagnosis.  As to the Veteran's lay statements, while Veteran is competent to testify as to some matters of diagnosis and etiology, the question of whether a Veteran has a diagnosis of PTSD is the type of medical issue as to an internal, non-observable process as to which lay testimony is not competent.  See Clemons v. Shinseki, 23 Vet. App. 1, 6 (2009) ("It is generally the province of medical professionals to diagnose or label a mental condition, not the claimant"); 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304 (f) (specifically requiring medical evidence diagnosing PTSD).  Consequently, the Veteran's statements as to whether he has a diagnosis of PTSD are not competent.

Next, the Board finds that the Veteran's psychiatric disorders were not chronic in service.  Service treatment records are negative for any complaints, diagnoses, or treatment for a psychiatric disorder.  In a March 1987 VA periodic medical examination, the Veteran had a normal clinical psychiatric evaluation and a psychiatric disorder was not noted.  As such, symptoms of a psychiatric disorder were not chronic in service.

The Board further finds that the Veteran's symptoms of delusions have not been continuous since service separation.  The Veteran was not diagnosed with a delusional disorder until August 2012, nearly 20 years after his military service.  The Board finds that this evidence tends to show that the Veteran's symptoms of delusions began many years after service separation.  See Maxson v. Gober, 230 F.3d 1330, 1333 (Fed. Cir. 2000) (lengthy period of absence of medical complaints for condition can be considered as a factor for consideration in deciding a claim).  For these reasons, the Board finds that the Veteran's psychiatric disorder did not manifest to a compensable degree within one year from service separation and symptoms of a psychiatric disorder have not been continuous since service separation.  

Next, the Board finds that the weight of the evidence of record does not demonstrate that the Veteran's psychiatric disorders are related to service.  The evidence includes an August 2012 and an April 2016 VA examination reports.  The August 2012 and April 2016 VA examiners indicated that they reviewed the record and interviewed the Veteran.  Both VA examiners opined that the Veteran did not have PTSD.  The April 2016 VA examiner opined that the Veteran's delusional disorder and alcohol use disorder was unrelated to his military service.  The examiner commented that her opinion was based on thorough C-file review, review of all available medical records and current peer reviewed medical literature.  

The Board has also considered the Veteran's statements regarding his belief that his psychiatric disorders are related to service.  As a lay person, however, the Veteran does not have the requisite medical knowledge, training, or experience to be able to render a competent medical opinion regarding the cause of the medically complex psychiatric disorder of delusion, mental disorder, or PTSD.  See Kahana v. Shinseki, 24 Vet. App. 428, 437 (2011).  These psychiatric disorders are medically complex disease processes because of their multiple possible etiologies, require specialized testing to diagnose, and manifest symptomatology that may overlap with other psychiatric disorders.  Woehlaert v. Nicholson, 21 Vet. App. 456, 462 (2007) (holding that rheumatic fever is not a condition capable of lay diagnosis). 

For the reasons discussed above, a preponderance of the evidence is against the claim for service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder claimed as PTSD.  Because the preponderance of the evidence is against the Veteran's claim, the benefit of the doubt doctrine is not for application.  See 38 U.S.C. Â§ 5107; 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.102.


	ORDER

Entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder (claimed as posttraumatic stress disorder) is denied.  



____________________________________________
K. J. ALIBRANDO 
Veterans Law Judge, Board of Veterans' Appeals



Department of Veterans Affairs
